The text discusses the role of microRNAs (mir-200c) in cancer, specifically in breast, ovarian, and endometrial cancers. Mir-200c represses zeb1, a transcription factor involved in epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT), leading to the re-expression of e-cadherin and decreased cell migration and invasion. Mir-200c also directly targets tubb3, a common mechanism of resistance to microtubule-targeting agents, resulting in increased sensitivity to paclitaxel. However, not all cells exhibit the double negative feedback loop between mir-200c and zeb1, and some cells may not regain e-cadherin expression even with zeb1 repression. The text also mentions the use of various techniques such as transfection, western blotting, and real-time PCR to study the effects of mir-200c on cancer cells.
</summary>

<summary>
This study aimed to compare the relationship between the tape and the urethra in both the inside-out and outside-in transobturator sling (TOT) approaches using CT scan image analysis. Ten cadavers were operated on with each approach, and the tapes' trajectories were compared in a flat position. The mean full inner angle of the in-out TOT was 122 (95%CI: 107-136), while that of the out-in TOT was 144 (95%CI: 131-151) (p = 0.02). The differences between the tapes' inner angles were significant (mean difference of 19.8, median 19.0, wilcoxon signed rank test: p = 0.008). The use of tantalum wires threaded through the polypropylene-/prolene-tape in combination with three-dimensional CT-scanning provided a unique method to visualize midurethral tapes throughout their entire trajectory. The findings showed that both obturator approaches were u-shaped bands that headed backwards or dorsally, and the tape lies as a band behind the urethra. The in-out approach angulated around the urethra in a more acute fashion than the out-in approach. The study also revealed that the out-in tapes were more closely wrapped around the inferior ischio-pubic ramus than the in-out tapes and stayed closer to the vaginal wall, which could explain the increased risk of button-holing and vaginal angle injuries during an out-in procedure. The clinical implications from this study suggest that surgeons must pay more attention to the second half of the helical pass, whichever way they choose to go.
</summary>

They discussed the importance of creativity and teamwork in the project and the need for a larger budget to explore more innovative ideas. They also touched on the potential for market research and testing different versions of the product.
</summary>

During a post-legislative scrutiny session on the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015, Kirsty Williams, the Welsh Minister for Education, discussed the intentions of the upcoming post-compulsory education and training (PCET) Bill, addressing concerns about the balance of regulation for different types of educational institutions, the role of fee and access plans, and the importance of good governance in universities. The session also touched upon the potential for longer-term fee and access plans, the regulation of private providers, and the future of quality assurance in the sector.

During a post-legislative scrutiny session on the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015, Kirsty Williams AM, the Welsh Minister for Education, discussed the intentions for managing risks and amendments to the Act in the upcoming post-compulsory education and training Bill. The Act aimed to regulate institutions in Wales, safeguard public good, maintain fair access, and preserve institutional autonomy. The current legislation has been criticized for not achieving all strategic aims, and the new Bill will address these weaknesses. The Act's focus on institutional autonomy made it difficult for institutions to fulfill national outcomes, and the new legislation will introduce outcome agreements to address this issue. The current legislation did not regulate alternative private providers, and the new Bill will consider how to address this. The Act did not regulate part-time fees and postgraduate fees, and the intention is to continue this approach. The Act's powers of intervention were inflexible and hard to use, and the new legislation will create a more flexible regulatory regime.

Kirsty Williams AM, the Welsh Minister for Education, appeared before the Children, Young People and Education Committee to discuss the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015 during a post-legislative scrutiny session. She acknowledged that the Act would be superseded by the upcoming Post-Compulsory Education and Training (PCET) Bill. The Act aimed to regulate institutions in Wales, safeguard the contribution made to public good, maintain fair access, and preserve institutional autonomy. The Act has been criticized for limiting Welsh Government's policy leverage over the sector, but Williams believes that the remit letter and relationship with HEFCW have allowed for national priorities to be addressed. The Act's focus on individual institutions did not encourage collaboration, and the PCET Bill aims to address this by creating a framework that demands and encourages collaboration across the entirety of the sector. HEFCW's powers of intervention were discussed, with some concerns that they are inflexible and hard to use. Williams acknowledged these concerns but did not agree, stating that the powers are proportionate and that the commission, once established, would be structured in a way that allows for relationships to be built and soft regulation to be used. The consultation on the PCET reforms closed in summer 2018, and Williams has had ongoing dialogue with stakeholders since then regarding the future of fee and access plans. The current fee and access plans focus on inputs rather than outcomes and are evaluated on an annual basis, which some stakeholders feel is not effective. Williams expressed her preference for a longer-term approach to fee and access plans and a shift from yearly plans to something more strategic. The 2015 Act did not directly address issues around governance in the sector, but Williams has been working to establish a more direct relationship with chairs of universities and has supported an independent review of governance, which is currently underway. The review is chaired by Gillian Camm, the chair of the Leadership Foundation for Higher Education, and aims to advise on changes to governance. Williams is exploring how the PCET Bill could introduce a regulatory condition in respect of good governance and diversity in governing bodies. The Act required HEFCW to secure arrangements for the assessment of the quality of education provided by or on behalf of a regulated institution, which has caused difficulties for further education colleges. The PCET Bill will address this issue by clarifying the roles and responsibilities

During a post-legislative scrutiny session on the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015, Kirsty Williams AM, the Welsh Minister for Education, answered questions about the Act's effectiveness and potential improvements. She acknowledged that the Act had achieved some strategic aims but expressed the intention to supercede it with the new post-compulsory education and training Bill. Sian Gwenllian AM asked about the Act's fulfillment of government objectives and weaknesses. Kirsty Williams acknowledged that all four strategic aims were still relevant but that the legislation needed to be updated to address current circumstances. She also mentioned the importance of the report of this committee and the need to learn from experiences. Sian Gwenllian further asked if the legislation itself had hindered institutions from fulfilling national outcomes, to which Kirsty Williams responded that the remit letter had been an effective mechanism for influencing national priorities. The discussion also covered the regulation of private providers, fee and access plans, managing risk, and governance.
</summary>

Kirsty Williams AM, the Welsh Minister for Education, spoke about the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015 during a post-legislative scrutiny session. She mentioned that the Act will be superseded by the new Post-compulsory Education and Training (PCET) Bill, but there are experiences from the implementation of the 2015 Act that will be reflected in the new legislation. She acknowledged that the Act has had some weaknesses and that there are opportunities to strengthen it, particularly in relation to regulation, fair access, and institutional autonomy.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a post-legislative scrutiny session on the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015. Kirsty Williams AM, the Minister for Education, and Huw Morris, the director of the skills, higher education and lifelong learning group in Welsh Government, attended the meeting. The committee questioned the Minister about the Act's objectives, weaknesses, and the intention to repeal or amend it with the post-compulsory education and training Bill. The Minister acknowledged the importance of the Act's objectives but recognized the need for improvements and learning from experiences. They also discussed the role of charities in regulating private providers and the potential for future legislation to address governance issues in universities.

In the final detailed design meeting, the team discussed the look and feel design, user interface design, and evaluated the remote control product. The team presented a prototype, which included changes such as an LCD screen, a simpler design, and a number pad. The team also discussed the placement of the company logo and the use of colours. The team evaluated the project, discussing creativity, leadership, teamwork, and the use of tools such as the whiteboard and digital pens. The team suggested that producing a prototype earlier in the process and having more collaboration tools could have been beneficial. The team also noted that the PowerPoints and digital pens were clunky and distracting, and suggested having one computer for the team instead of each person bringing their own. The team concluded that the project was within budget and evaluated, and the final report was to be written by the project manager.

The team discussed the functional requirements for a remote control for a TV, focusing on simplicity and quick delivery due to time constraints. They decided on having a clap function to prevent losing the remote, ten number buttons, and a hidden panel for additional functions. They also considered having a menu function and a whistle or clap function to find the remote if lost. They decided against speech recognition due to potential cost and complexity. They plan to meet again to finalize the design and functions.

The group discussed the ease of making changes to a database format for linking up word transcripts and annotations. Some preferred making it hard to change, while others wanted it to be easy. They discussed the use of channelized output from Dave Gelbart's program as a starting point, but were unsure if it was the best option. They also considered using an existing format like the one developed by NIST, but decided against it due to the learning curve. They also discussed the possibility of using a relational database to store the information from the XML format. The group agreed to look into the ATLAS format and the P-file format, which is already in use at ICSI, and decide on a format based on its ease of use and compatibility with their tools.
</summary>

The project manager welcomed everyone to the kickoff meeting for designing a new remote control, emphasizing the importance of originality, trendiness, and user-friendliness. The team discussed the design process, which would consist of functional, conceptual, and desired design stages. They also drew their favorite animals on the whiteboard as an icebreaker activity. The team discussed the financial objectives of the project, aiming for a production cost lower than €12.5 and a selling price of twice that amount to target a profit of €50 million. They also discussed the need for the remote control to be multi-device, waterproof, and have few buttons. The team also suggested a whistle-activated remote control and a button for the TV to make the remote control beep when lost. During a scrutiny session on early childhood education and care in Wales, the Deputy Minister for Health and Social Services, Julie Morgan, discussed the Welsh Government's approach to early years provision, which aims to support both children and parents. The Government's objectives include simplifying the complex early years system and extending the childcare offer to parents in education and training. The childcare offer, which was initially intended to be delivered through HMRC, was changed to a local authority-led system due to technical difficulties with the Welsh language standards and concerns about flexibility. Flying Start, a targeted early intervention programme, currently reaches about 23% of children in Wales, with around 45% of those children living in poverty. The Government is looking at ways to make Flying Start more accessible to a wider group of children.

During a scrutiny session on early childhood education and care, Welsh Government officials discussed their approach to early years provision and the challenges of simplifying the system. They emphasized the importance of both supporting children's development and helping parents return to work. The Welsh Government is currently testing different models in eight local authorities to improve accessibility and take-up of early years services. The Deputy Minister acknowledged that there are significant differences in the amount of early childhood education and care provision available in different parts of Wales and that the current system is complex. The Welsh Government is planning to expand the childcare offer to include parents in education and training, and they are reviewing the longer-term implications of a universal childcare offer. The Childcare Funding (Wales) Act 2019, which aimed to streamline the childcare funding system by using HMRC to administer payments, has been suspended due to difficulties with implementing the Welsh language standards. The committee expressed concern about the change in position on this issue.

During a scrutiny session on early childhood education and care, Julie Morgan, Deputy Minister for Health and Social Services in the Welsh Government, discussed the objectives of their approach, which includes supporting both children and parents. She acknowledged the historical focus on getting parents into work and the need to simplify the system, particularly with regard to funding and the connection from birth to school. Morgan mentioned ongoing pilot projects aimed at improving accessibility and take-up of early years services, and the possibility of extending the childcare offer to parents in education and training. She also addressed concerns about the cost of transitioning from a temporary arrangement with local authorities to a permanent system, and the potential for a longer-term review of the childcare offer. The discussion touched on the Flying Start program, which targets areas with high levels of income-dependent households, and its impact on children living in poverty. Morgan acknowledged that only about 45% of children in Flying Start areas are in poverty, and expressed a desire to make the benefits of Flying Start more accessible to a wider group of children.

During a meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee, Deputy Minister Julie Morgan discussed the Welsh Government's approach to early childhood education and care. She emphasized the importance of supporting both children and parents, with a focus on simplifying the system and improving accessibility and take-up of services. The Deputy Minister also mentioned ongoing pilot projects and the potential expansion of the childcare offer to include parents in education and training. When asked about the cost of transitioning from a temporary arrangement with local authorities to a permanent system, the Deputy Minister indicated that initial estimates suggest it would be less than the cost proposed by HMRC. The committee expressed concern about previous assurances regarding the Welsh language and the sudden emergence of issues with HMRC's IT systems.

The Welsh Government, through its European transition team, is preparing for the potential impact of Brexit on higher and further education in Wales. The team is engaging with institutions and sector bodies to understand their specific needs and concerns, and is working to mitigate risks and secure funding for EU students and staff. The team is also exploring opportunities to boost international marketing and recruitment to support the sector during this time of uncertainty.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee held an evidence session on the impact of Brexit on higher and further education in Wales. Kirsty Williams, Cabinet Secretary for Education, and Eluned Morgan, Minister for Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning, attended the session with their officials. The committee discussed the preparedness of Welsh universities for Brexit and the solutions being proposed. The Welsh Government has been working closely with higher and further education institutions since September 2016 to understand the potential impact of Brexit. The HE sector has been looking at their own institution-specific challenges, such as exposure to EU students and funding from Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+. The FE sector, which is more locally anchored, has a much lower number of EU students and staff, but faces challenges with European Social Fund funding and apprenticeships. The Welsh Government is engaging with the FE sector and ColegauCymru to address these concerns. The European transition team within the Welsh Government is providing governance structure for the Welsh Government as a whole in relation to European transition. The team is working to provide clarity and certainty for the HE and FE sectors and to mitigate the risks of Brexit. The committee discussed the drop in EU student applications to Welsh universities and the potential impact on the balance of high, medium, and low-tariff universities in Wales. The Welsh Government is exploring the possibility of looking at different immigration rules for international and EU students who may wish to study in Wales. The committee also discussed the sustainability of higher and further education in Wales and the need for multi-year funding settlements for both sectors beyond Brexit.

Kirsty Williams, the Cabinet Secretary for Education in Wales, discussed the potential impact of Brexit on higher and further education during a committee hearing. She mentioned ongoing work with institutions to understand their exposure to European Union students and funding, as well as efforts to mitigate risks and secure funding for international marketing and recruitment.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a meeting to discuss the impact of Brexit on higher and further education. Kirsty Williams, Cabinet Secretary for Education, and Eluned Morgan AM, Minister for Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning, attended the meeting along with their officials. Suzy Davies asked about the preparedness of the Welsh Government for Brexit and the research done on the impact on higher and further education. Kirsty Williams explained that the Welsh Government started a higher education and further education group in September 2016 to understand the potential impact of Brexit. The funding for much of the activity is believed to be secured until December 2020, but ongoing work is being done to refine approaches as the situation becomes clearer. The exposure and potential impact of leaving the EU on individual institutions varies greatly. There are formal risk assessments being done, but they are not yet available for scrutiny. The FE sector is much more anchored in their communities and the number of EU students and staff is significantly lower than in higher education. The impact on FE of European social fund funding and apprenticeships is a concern. The Welsh Government is keeping in touch with the FE sector and letting them know about the Home Office settled status and what they can do to protect the 71 EU staff. The European transition team is a central coordinating group that pulls together all the leads in each department to provide governance structure for the Welsh Government in relation to European transition. The team provides the governance structure and leads discussions with the Department for Exiting the European Union, No. 10, and the Joint Ministerial Committee. The Welsh Government is working to ensure that universities and colleges are prepared for Brexit and is investing in international marketing and recruitment to mitigate the potential impact.

In a functional design meeting, Marketing discussed user requirements for a new remote control, suggesting a minimalist design with a joystick for basic functions and a small LCD screen. They also proposed the addition of a speaker and an LED for locating the remote control. The Industrial Designer suggested incorporating a transmitter and considering the feasibility of an LCD screen and speaker. Marketing mentioned the importance of the software side of the interface and the need to research user preferences. The Project Manager asked for feedback on the minimalist approach and suggested the possibility of building the transmitter into the television. The team discussed the importance of the company slogan and the potential use of the double arcs as the enter button. The meeting concluded with the agreement to further explore the design ideas.

In the third project meeting, the team discussed the conceptual design phase, focusing on the conceptual specification of components and trend-watching. The team agreed on the requirements, which include teletext, a docking station, audio signal, a small screen, and some extra buttons. The target market is sixty to eighty-year-old customers. The team presented findings from market research, which indicated that a fancy design is the most important factor for older people, followed by innovativeness and ease of use. The team discussed the energy source, deciding against kinetic energy due to its potential impact on production price and image. The team also discussed the interface design, deciding against voice recognition due to its potential cost increase and limited ease of use. The team agreed to use a standard remote control with changeable case covers as an advantage point. The team decided to design one remote with a fancy wooden or plastic cover and leave the form as a normal shape. The next meeting will focus on the look-and-feel design, user interface design, and product evaluation.

The team discussed the design of a remote control, evaluating its features and costs. They evaluated the design's fanciness, innovation, and ease of use for both younger and older users. They also discussed the use of materials, such as rubber and LCD screens. The team considered adding a microphone and speech recognition, but these features increased the cost. They decided to remove some features, such as the sample speaker and single curved design, to reduce the cost to under €12.50. They also considered using a wooden or titanium material instead of rubber. The team then moved on to discussing the finance aspect of the project, preparing to calculate the production costs.

<summary>
During a Children, Young People and Education Committee meeting, Kirsty Williams AM, Cabinet Secretary for Education, discussed the use and effectiveness of the Pupil Development Grant (PDG) in Wales. The PDG is primarily used to support children eligible for free school meals, but it can also be used for other vulnerable learners, such as looked-after and adopted children. The Cabinet Secretary acknowledged that there is a need to improve the educational outcomes for these children and that PDG has not been effective enough in this regard. She also mentioned that there is a lack of awareness among schools about the availability of PDG for looked-after children. The Cabinet Secretary announced that an evaluation of the use of PDG for looked-after children is being conducted by ICF consulting and the results will be made public before the summer recess. The discussion also touched upon the Schools Challenge Cymru programme, which aimed to improve the performance of underperforming schools, and the Cabinet Secretary expressed confidence that the lessons learned from this programme are being applied to the wider school improvement agenda.
</summary>

The Welsh Government was questioned about the effective use of the Pupil Development Grant (PDG) in schools during a Children, Young People and Education Committee hearing. Kirsty Williams, Cabinet Secretary for Education, acknowledged that some schools have used PDG to provide universal interventions, but stressed that individual interventions should only be targeted at children eligible for free school meals. She also mentioned the importance of using evidence-based interventions and the role of regional advisers in ensuring consistent practice. The discussion also touched on the need to improve attendance and reduce exclusions for children eligible for free school meals, as well as the potential impact of PDG on looked-after and adopted children. The Cabinet Secretary expressed her intention to publish a report on the impact of PDG on looked-after and adopted children later this year.

The Welsh Government discussed the use and effectiveness of the Pupil Development Grant (PDG) during a Children, Young People and Education Committee meeting. The PDG is targeted at children eligible for free school meals, but it can also be used for universal interventions if they have a disproportionate effect on these children. The Cabinet Secretary for Education, Kirsty Williams, acknowledged concerns about the blurring of eligibility and the predominant focus on low-attaining free school meal pupils. She emphasized the importance of individual interventions being targeted at eligible children, but also acknowledged the potential for whole-school approaches that demonstrate a disproportionate impact on free school meal pupils. The PDG is also used to support more able and talented children, with examples given of successful initiatives like the 'window on the world' bus in Pembrokeshire. The use of PDG for looked-after and adopted children was also discussed, with concerns raised about awareness and visibility of the funding for these children. The Cabinet Secretary acknowledged the need for greater awareness and encouraged parents to discuss their children's education with schools. The impact of PDG on attendance and exclusions was also discussed, with a focus on the importance of a multi-agency approach and early intervention. The Schools Challenge Cymru programme was mentioned as an example of successful interventions, but concerns were raised about the sustainability of improvements after the programme ended. The Cabinet Secretary expressed confidence in the ongoing support for schools and the importance of strong school leadership and collaborative working.

<summary>
During a Welsh Assembly Children, Young People and Education Committee meeting, Kirsty Williams AM, Cabinet Secretary for Education, discussed the use of the Pupil Development Grant (PDG) for vulnerable learners, including those who are looked-after and adopted. The PDG is intended to support individual interventions for children eligible for free school meals, but it can also be used for universal interventions if they have a disproportionate effect on free school meal pupils. The Cabinet Secretary acknowledged concerns about the guidance and awareness of how the PDG should be used effectively and expressed the need for new regional advisers to ensure consistent practice. She also mentioned the importance of using evidence-based interventions and the Sutton Trust toolkit. The Cabinet Secretary was asked about the eligibility for free school meals being the best measure for identifying vulnerable learners and responded that it is the best available measure in the absence of anything better. She also mentioned the potential impact of universal credit on the identification of relative need. The Cabinet Secretary discussed the challenges of longer term planning due to the annual eligibility for free school meals and the possibility of greater flexibility in the system. She also mentioned the importance of addressing the attainment gap for more able and talented pupils and gave examples of good practice in this area.
</summary>

The text is a transcript from a Welsh Assembly Children, Young People and Education Committee hearing on targeted funding to improve educational outcomes. They acknowledged challenges in ensuring effective use of the PDG and the importance of leadership and collaboration in school improvement. They also discussed ongoing efforts to improve attendance, reduce exclusions, and address the attainment gap for vulnerable learners.

Dr. Frank Atherton, the Chief Medical Officer for Wales, and Nathan Cook, the head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government, discussed the 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales' draft strategy during a committee meeting. They emphasized the importance of focusing on children and young people to prevent future generations from facing the same obesity issues as the current generation. They have engaged with children and young people through various fora, including schools and youth groups, to gather their perspectives. The strategy may include a target to reduce obesity, but the specifics are still under consultation. The investment needed to implement the plan is being assessed, and it may depend on the targets set. The consultation process will include discussions on leadership, partnership working, healthy environments, and healthy settings.

During a Children, Young People and Education Committee meeting, Dr Frank Atherton, the Chief Medical Officer for Wales, and Nathan Cook, the head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government, discussed the 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales' draft strategy. They emphasized the importance of addressing childhood obesity and involving children and young people in the consultation process. The strategy includes a review of the clinical obesity pathway and a commitment to updating it. The consultation also covers the importance of the first 1,000 days and the need to support low-income families in making healthy choices. The health system needs to respond by providing better access to dietetic support and redesigning the pathway. The consultation is open for input, and the committee welcomed the opportunity to contribute from a children's perspective. The committee noted several letters and papers, including those related to CAMHS provision, the new curriculum, and Brexit's impact on children. The committee resolved to exclude the public from the remainder of the meeting.

They emphasized the importance of engaging children and young people in the consultation process and the need for a whole-system approach to address the issue. The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a meeting to scrutinize the draft strategy 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales.' Dr. Frank Atherton, the Chief Medical Officer for Wales, and Nathan Cook, head of the healthy and active branch at the Welsh Government, were present to discuss the strategy. The strategy aims to address childhood obesity and improve overall health by focusing on children and young people. The strategy includes engagement with children and young people, who have provided input through various fora, including schools and youth groups. The consultation includes the possibility of setting targets to reduce obesity, but the exact nature of these targets is still under consideration. The strategy also includes a focus on leadership and partnership working, with a national implementation board to be accountable to Ministers. Data on childhood obesity is currently collected through the child measurement programme, but there is a need for more longitudinal data to better understand the issue. The strategy includes measures such as legislating for restricting price promotions and banning energy drinks, and the possibility of using the planning system to restrict hot food takeaways near schools. The strategy also emphasizes the importance of creating healthy settings, including schools, and the need for local leadership to drive change.

During a research meeting, the group discussed various issues related to speech recognition technology. One topic was the effect of room noise on speech recognition, specifically the use of a PDA microphone that picked up noise from an air conditioner. The group also discussed the dynamic range of the system and the potential impact of quantization error. They considered changing a capacitor on the input box or using a digital filter to address the issue. Another topic was the use of different filters during data processing, specifically the high-pass filter in Feacalc. The group also discussed the importance of using the same filtering options consistently and the potential impact of different filtering methods on speech recognition performance.
</summary>

<summary>

They decided against using a dynamo for power, opting instead for a rechargeable battery. The team agreed to create a model in clay and save the design in the Project Documents folder. The Project Manager asked the team to work on the design and provided further instructions. However, there were issues with accessing the shared documents and recovering deleted information.
</summary>

<summary>
During a meeting, the group discussed various techniques for improving speech recognition performance, including Wiener filtering and spectral subtraction. PhD B presented his results using Wiener filtering, which showed a thirty percent improvement over the baseline but did not meet the desired fifty percent improvement. He also tried a second stage of Wiener filtering, which improved the results further to fifty-six point four six percent. PhD D discussed his experiments with spectral subtraction, which yielded negative energies in some cases. The group discussed the implications of negative energies and potential solutions, such as adding speech-shaped noise or not doing subtraction in bins with negative numbers. They also discussed the possibility of leaving negative numbers as is or reflecting them back up. PhD D also mentioned trying nonlinear smoothing on the gain trajectory of the spectral subtraction filter to reduce musical noise.
</summary>

During a meeting, Professor B discussed the issue of voice activity detectors in speech recognition systems with PhD students. He mentioned that French Telecom Alcatel and their team had been using a voice activity detector, which was not disclosed earlier, leading to competition and disagreements among the teams. The teams agreed to re-evaluate the systems without voice activity detectors or modify the algorithms. Professor B also discussed the importance of understanding the impact of compressing individual dimensions in a multidimensional Gaussian model and how it affects the importance of certain components. He suggested modifying the standard deviation of the model to de-weight certain components and compressing the test data to match. However, there was a disagreement on whether to change the mean of the test data or not. The discussion ended with the consensus that adjusting the model's variance could be an alternative way to decrease the importance of certain components.
</summary>

The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales (HEFCW) appeared before the Children, Young People and Education Committee to discuss the impact of Brexit on Welsh higher education. Dr. David Blaney, the Chief Executive of HEFCW, and Bethan Owen, the Director of Institutional Engagement, provided evidence on the current situation and future concerns. The sector is currently facing financial pressures due to changes in student funding and the uncertainty surrounding EU student recruitment and research funding. Institutions are working to attract more students and funding from within the UK and internationally. The Welsh Government is also working to support the sector through the Reid report and potential transition funding. The sector is also concerned about the potential loss of EU research funding and the impact on collaborations and networks. The HEFCW is working to build the capacity for Wales to attract more charitable sector research funding. The committee noted several letters and papers before moving into private session.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a meeting to discuss the impact of Brexit on higher and further education in Wales. The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales provided evidence, highlighting the uncertainty surrounding the future of EU student recruitment and research funding. The council also mentioned the need for increased investment in Welsh universities to remain competitive and attract more research funding from the charitable sector. The committee discussed the potential impact of Brexit on the sector, including the loss of EU students and research funding, and the need for the Welsh Government to provide clarity and transition funding to mitigate these effects.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a meeting to discuss the impact of Brexit on higher and further education in Wales. The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales (HEFCW) provided evidence, with Dr David Blaney, the chief executive, and Bethan Owen, the director of institutional engagement, in attendance. They discussed the potential impact of Brexit on Welsh universities, including the uncertainty surrounding EU student applications and funding. The HE sector in Wales is significant, contributing about £5 billion annually and creating 50,000 jobs. The HEFCW is concerned about the sustainability of the sector, particularly in relation to EU funding and student recruitment. EU students make up about 8% of the total income for Welsh universities, with approximately £129 million coming from EU sources in 2017-18. The HEFCW is also working to ensure student protection in the event of Brexit, including maintaining the quality of education and addressing the financial pressures on institutions. The Welsh Government is currently considering the Reid report, which recommends increasing investment in research and innovation to maintain and strengthen the research base in Wales. The HEFCW also highlighted the importance of engaging in conversations with research councils and attracting charitable sector research funding to Wales. The committee also noted several letters and papers, including one from the Cabinet Secretary for Education on the school organization code, and one from the Minister for Children, Older People and Social Care on the Childcare Funding (Wales) Bill. The committee then moved into private session.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a meeting to discuss the impact of Brexit on higher and further education in Wales. The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales (HEFCW) provided evidence, with Dr David Blaney, the chief executive, and Bethan Owen, the director of institutional engagement, in attendance. They discussed the potential financial and recruitment pressures facing Welsh universities due to Brexit, including the uncertainty surrounding EU student applications and funding. The HE sector in Wales contributes about £5 billion to the Welsh economy and employs 50,000 people. The HEFCW is concerned about the potential loss of EU funding and the impact on research collaborations and networks. EU students make up about 8% of the total income for Welsh universities, and there are signs of difficulties in playing in EU collaborative research activities. The HEFCW is also seeing a decrease in EU and non-EU applications to Welsh institutions, contrasting with an increase in England. The Welsh Government is expected to receive a 'Diamond dividend' from Brexit, but the exact amount and how much will go to HE is uncertain. The HE sector is currently managing deficits and planning for various scenarios, but the lack of clarity on the Brexit deal and the Diamond dividend is causing uncertainty. The HEFCW is working with universities to encourage international mobility and funding from their own fee income. The HEFCW has a statutory duty to assess the academic quality of higher education institutions in Wales and is concerned about the potential impact of Brexit on this, particularly in relation to EU students and research collaborations. The HEFCW is also working to build the capacity for Welsh universities to attract more charitable sector research funding.

She mentioned that many young people and teachers have reported positive experiences with the qualification.

Suzy Davies also asked about inconsistency in the way the Welsh baccalaureate is delivered and the impact on the value learners attach to it. Kirsty Williams AM acknowledged the variability in delivery and the need for greater consistency, which is being addressed through a design group and a stakeholder group.

During the Children, Young People and Education Committee meeting, the discussion focused on the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill. The Deputy Minister for Health and Social Services, Julie Morgan, responded to concerns raised by Janet Finch-Saunders AM regarding the opposition to the Bill from individuals and parents who do not support it. Morgan emphasized that the Bill aims to protect children's rights and ensure they have the same protection from physical punishment as adults. She acknowledged that people have different views and that the consultation process has been important for hearing those views. The United Nations Committee on the Rights of the Child recognizes that any physical punishment of children, however minor, is incompatible with their human rights. The implementation of the Bill will involve an awareness campaign and the establishment of an implementation group to address concerns and issues that may arise. The group will include representatives from the police, Crown Prosecution Service, Association of Directors of Education in Wales, and the Welsh Local Government Association, among others. The group will look at parenting advice and support, data collection, evaluation and monitoring, operations, procedures and processes, and out-of-court disposals and diversions. The Bill does not create a new offence but removes the defence to an offence of common assault. The police and Crown Prosecution Service have indicated their willingness to work closely with the Welsh Government on the implementation of the Bill. The Bill is expected to have minimal impact on public services and resources, but the Welsh Government is committed to collecting data to monitor the impact of the legislation.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a virtual meeting to discuss the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales. Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning, attended the meeting. The Minister expressed gratitude to all those involved in keeping schools open and supporting children's learning during the pandemic. She outlined the challenges facing the education system, including the need to ensure the safety and well-being of children and staff, communicate clearly with parents and staff, and consider which groups of children should return to school first. The Minister also acknowledged the importance of international evidence and collaboration with other nations. She confirmed that schools are not currently relaxing any restrictions and that testing will be crucial in the next phase. The committee asked about the number of children attending school hubs, the safety measures in place, and the support for vulnerable children and those with additional learning needs. The Minister provided details on the number of children attending and the measures being taken to ensure their safety. She also announced additional funding for school counselling services and efforts to ensure all children have access to technology for remote learning. The committee asked about the impact on examinations and the awarding of grades, as well as the moratorium on unconditional university offers and student maintenance loans. The Minister confirmed that a moratorium on unconditional offers exists until May 1st and that discussions are ongoing. She also confirmed that students will not be asked to reimburse maintenance loans for living at home instead of in halls of residence. The committee thanked the Minister and her officials for attending and will write to her with any further questions. The committee then resolved to meet in private for the remainder of the meeting.

Kirsty Williams AM, the Welsh Minister for Education, addressed the Children, Young People and Education Committee regarding the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales. She expressed gratitude to all those involved in keeping schools open for vulnerable children and key workers. She emphasized the importance of protecting the health and well-being of children and staff. The Minister outlined five principles to guide decisions on when schools will reopen, which include considering the safety and well-being of children and staff, communicating clearly with parents and staff, and planning for the operational challenges of reopening schools. She acknowledged that testing will be crucial in the next phase and that schools will not return to normal soon. The Minister also discussed the challenges of supporting vulnerable children and those with additional learning needs during the pandemic. She announced PS1.25 million for school counselling services and efforts to ensure all children have access to technology for remote learning. The Minister acknowledged concerns about the attainment gap and the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, and promised to work with local authorities to ensure all children have access to digital resources for learning at home. She also addressed questions on examinations, vocational qualifications, and higher education.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a virtual meeting to discuss the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales. Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning, attended the meeting. The Minister expressed gratitude to all those involved in keeping schools open for vulnerable children and key workers. She acknowledged the challenges faced due to the pandemic and the efforts of teachers, teaching assistants, and parents in keeping children learning at home. The Minister outlined the principles that will guide decisions on when schools will reopen, including the safety and well-being of children and staff, clear communication, and a phased approach. She emphasized that a return to normal is not imminent and that testing, tracing, and quarantine will be crucial in the next phase. The Minister also discussed the support for vulnerable children, the importance of mental health, and the continuity of learning. She announced PS1.25 million for school counselling and efforts to ensure all children have access to technology and connectivity for remote learning. The Minister acknowledged the challenges for vocational learners and promised to work on a solution for those who have no choice but to wait for a vocational assessment. The meeting ended with a resolution to meet in private for the remainder of the agenda.

In the virtual meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee, Kirsty Williams AM, the Welsh Minister for Education, discussed the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales. She expressed gratitude to those keeping schools open and helping children learn at home. She outlined five principles for reopening schools, emphasizing the importance of safety, communication, and planning. She acknowledged the challenges of testing, school absences, and supporting vulnerable children, but assured that schools will not be relaxing restrictions imminently. She also addressed concerns about the attainment gap and the use of technology for learning.

The Welsh Government discussed the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on education in Wales, with a focus on supporting vulnerable children and ensuring continuity of learning. The Minister announced that schools will close for statutory education provision but will have a new purpose of supporting those most in need, including children of key workers and those receiving free school meals. The Government is working to provide digital tools and resources for distance learning and will announce further details shortly.

The Welsh Government, led by Education Minister Kirsty Williams, announced the closure of all schools in Wales due to the coronavirus pandemic. The new purpose of schools will be to support vulnerable children, including those with additional learning needs, and to provide childcare for the children of key workers. The government is working to ensure continuity of learning through digital tools and other means. The decision not to proceed with summer exams was also announced, with students to be awarded grades based on their work up to that point. The government is also considering emergency legislation to provide flexibility in education and childcare provisions.

The Welsh Government discussed the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on education in Wales during an evidence session with Kirsty Williams, Minister for Education, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, Huw Morris, group director for skills, higher education and lifelong learning, and Rob Orford, chief scientific adviser for health. The Minister assured that the priority is to protect staff and pupils in schools while ensuring continuity of education. Schools will close from the following day but will have a new purpose, including supporting vulnerable children and ensuring continuity of learning. The decision not to proceed with summer exams was made due to public health concerns, and learners will be awarded grades based on a range of information. The Minister thanked everyone working in education settings for their hard work and urged everyone to continue working together to face the challenges posed by the coronavirus. The Minister also mentioned that discussions are ongoing with universities and colleges regarding their closure and the impact on students, including maintenance payments and mental health support.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a scrutiny session on the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill. Witnesses included Sally Jenkins from the Association of Directors of Social Services, Alastair Birch from Pembrokeshire County Council representing the Association of Directors of Education Wales, and Councillor Huw David from Bridgend County Borough Council as the Welsh Local Government Association spokesperson for health and social care. The witnesses discussed their general support for the Bill and why they believe the current law is ineffective or unclear. They emphasized the importance of upholding the rights of the child and the need for clarity in the legislation. The witnesses also discussed the potential impact of the Bill on social services, education, and awareness raising. They acknowledged the need for resources and a major awareness-raising campaign to support families and prevent unnecessary referrals to social services. The witnesses also discussed the importance of involving families and offering support to prevent the need for intervention. The committee also discussed the potential unintended consequences of the Bill, including the potential impact on emergency and out-of-hours local authority services and the importance of awareness raising. The witnesses expressed confidence that teachers and other educational professionals will be clear about how to support the implementation of the Bill and that the duty to report significant harm will always remain.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a scrutiny session on the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill. Witnesses included Sally Jenkins from the Association of Directors of Social Services, Alastair Birch from Pembrokeshire County Council representing the Association of Directors of Education Wales, and Councillor Huw David from Bridgend County Borough Council as the Welsh Local Government Association spokesperson for health and social care. The witnesses expressed their general support for the Bill and criticized the current law for being ineffective and unclear. They emphasized the importance of upholding the rights of the child and ensuring that children's voices are heard. The witnesses also discussed the potential harm of physical punishment on children and how it can lead to more serious forms of abuse. They acknowledged the need for greater clarity around the definition of corporal punishment but emphasized the importance of simplicity in the Bill. The witnesses also discussed the importance of awareness raising and training for professionals in education and social services. They expressed confidence that teachers and others working in educational settings will be clear about how to support the implementation of the Bill and that the duty to report significant harm will always remain. The witnesses also discussed the importance of investment in preventative services and support for families. They acknowledged that there may be costs associated with the implementation of the Bill but were committed to working with Welsh Government to identify those costs as quickly as possible.

They emphasized the importance of upholding the rights of the child and the need for clarity in the law regarding physical punishment. <summary>
The group discussed various issues related to their research project, including the NSF ITR proposal, transcriptions, and naming conventions for files. They talked about the challenges of dealing with overlapping speech and the importance of accurately identifying speakers and distinguishing between voiced and unvoiced sounds. They also discussed the potential for using harmonics to distinguish between single and multiple speakers and the need to normalize frequency ranges for accurate analysis. The group also raised the issue of handling breaths in the audio signal and whether they should be removed or kept for realism.
</summary>

The group met to discuss various aspects of their research project. They began by discussing the NSF ITR proposal, with Professor A providing an update on the status of the proposal and the upcoming full proposal due date. They also talked about the transcriptions, with Postdoc F sharing his findings on the challenges of transcribing channel-by-channel and the potential benefits of doing so.

Grad B brought up the issue of naming conventions for files, suggesting that all files should have the same length for easier sorting. They also discussed the importance of accurately identifying speakers and distinguishing between voiced and unvoiced sounds.

Professor A suggested using the ratio of energy in the harmonics to the total energy in the spectrum as a way to distinguish between overlapping speech and single speech. They also discussed the potential for using the instantaneous frequency to study harmonics and the challenges of applying the rules proposed in a paper on the subject.

Postdoc F raised the issue of handling breaths in the audio signal, suggesting that they might be able to be eliminated from the signal for efficiency but acknowledging that they are a natural part of speech. The group agreed that any application using their corpus would likely have to cope with breaths.

Finally, they discussed the potential for using harmonics to distinguish between single and multiple speakers and the need to normalize frequency ranges for accurate analysis. They also touched on the importance of considering the length and front size of windows when calculating instantaneous frequency.

During the Children, Young People and Education Committee, Kirsty Williams, the Minister for Education, discussed the role of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) in the Welsh Government's school improvement journey, the use of powers under the School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2013, and the national evaluation and improvement resource. She also addressed questions about the effectiveness of investment in school standards and the identification and support of schools causing concern. The Minister emphasized the importance of self-evaluation, the ongoing relationship with the OECD, and the need for a more robust approach to school improvement.

The Welsh Government's relationship with the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) involves regular reviews of the state of Welsh education. The OECD's latest report on Welsh education will be published in March 2023. The Welsh Government encourages external evaluation to ensure self-evaluation of the entire system and Welsh Government. The School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2013 gives local authorities the power to intervene in schools if necessary, with some successes reported. The national evaluation and improvement resource is being developed to support self-evaluation across the system, with Estyn playing a key role. The resource is expected to be introduced across the system in September 2020. The investment in school standards has been significant, with 50% of the funding directed towards professional learning for teachers. The categorisation system is used to identify schools that need support, with a focus on secondary schools that have been identified as needing improvement for some time. A new approach is being piloted to address this issue, involving a multi-agency panel working with schools to support improvement. The consortia have been criticized for inconsistent and ineffective work, but the Minister believes they are valuable for delivering school improvement services at scale. The strategic delivery group, chaired by Professor Dylan Jones, is reviewing the role of the middle tier to eliminate duplication and improve collaboration.

Performance measures in education have changed, making it more challenging to compare trends over time. The interim performance measures will be in place for two to three years while the new curriculum and qualifications are developed.

During a Children, Young People and Education Committee meeting in 2015, Kirsty Williams, the Welsh Minister for Education, discussed the role of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) in the Welsh Government's school improvement journey. She explained that the OECD was involved in a rapid review of the state of Welsh education at the beginning of the Assembly term and provided feedback that informed the publication of the national mission. She also spoke about the national evaluation and improvement resource, which is intended to help schools evaluate their strengths, weaknesses, and areas for improvement. The Minister expressed her belief that the investment in school standards has been effective, particularly in terms of professional learning for teachers. She also discussed the importance of early identification and intervention for schools causing concern, and the use of a multi-agency approach to support improvement in those schools. The Minister acknowledged that 11% of secondary schools have been judged as unsatisfactory in the last two academic years, and she is working on a new approach to address this issue. She also addressed questions about the role and effectiveness of the consortia, and the ongoing work of Professor Dylan Jones's strategic delivery group.

The OECD's latest report on Welsh education is expected to be published in March 2023. The Welsh Government uses the School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2013 to intervene in schools that require support, with local authorities taking the lead in most cases. The national evaluation and improvement resource is being developed to help schools evaluate their strengths and weaknesses and improve their performance. The investment in school standards has been significant in this Assembly term, with a focus on professional learning for teachers and staff.

In "The Secret In the Soil," Booth and Brennan investigate the murders of Frank Curtis and Emma Billings, who were both found in a compost pile. They suspect one of the farmers who uses the compost facility, Charlie Rogan, but discover that Kat Curtis, Frank's daughter, is the actual killer. She confesses that she killed Emma in a fit of jealousy and fear of her father's infidelity, and later lured Frank to the compost facility and killed him in self-defense. Charlie Rogan was arrested for the murders but was later exonerated. The team also learns that Frank and Emma were half-siblings, adding a new layer of complexity to the case. Throughout the investigation, Booth and Brennan's partnership is put to the test, and they must navigate their professional and personal relationship while solving the case.

In the scene at the bar, Phoebe suggests that Abbey get Sean another drink despite the bar limit. Phoebe and Cole discuss their relationship and Phoebe asks him if he's hiding anything from her. Cole assures her that he's not. The Seer, observing from the underworld, smiles.
